Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Solar Concentrator Unit for Low-Cost Metal Additive Manufacturing
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to provide access to a solar heat source for controlled high temperature applications using minimal, low-cost equipment. The proposed Solar Concentrator Unit (SCU) is the first step to providing individuals and underserved communities with the freedom of a low-cost alternative to many of their most pressing manufacturing and materials processing needs. The SCU produces no emissions in its heat generation, requires no fuel costs, and can be used in remote locations to deliver precision control to high temperature thermal processes. Many new applications become available to market participants through the proposed innovation with the most notable commercial outcome being a multi-material additive manufacturing (i.e. 3D printing) system capable of producing custom metal and glass parts. Additional applications for the SCU include welding; recycling of waste material into useful feedstocks; pyrolysis of waste streams to render them chemically and biologically inert; sanitizing medical equipment in disaster response operations; and very high temperature materials science research by individuals and research institutions.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project explores the design and performance of a SCU for delivering high temperatures in the range of 65 ?C to 2,200 ?C over long durations (6+ hours). The technology relies on concentrated solar energy as the primary heat source with the proposed innovation being a feedback control system for maintaining temperature of a receiver plane to within +/-5% of an operating value. The proposed innovation addresses the limitations of existing methods for concentrating solar energy which lack temperature control and whose consistency of output thermal flux varies with time of day, sun position, cloud cover, and atmospheric conditions. This Phase I project will consist of development of a SCU prototype to conduct characterization tests on output solar flux and flux density under varying solar conditions. The expected outcome of this project will be to prove feasibility of the proposed design concept and evaluate its use for controlled, high temperature applications. The performance characteristics of the SCU will be fully explored in Phase I and the design of the SCU will allow for development of modular Thermal Processing Units in Phase II to interface with the concentrated solar spot produced by the SCU.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In Phase I, Blueshift, LLC d/b/a Outward Technologies developed a feedback and control system for powering precision thermal processes with concentrated solar energy. This work focused on developing and testing a Solar Concentrator Unit (SCU) that can be used for 3D printing with high temperature materials like metal, glass, and lunar regolith. Testing with the SCU demonstrated heating of powders to temperatures greater than 2,600 ?C, precision control over the temperature to within ?1%, spot size control down to 1.6 mm spot diameters, and rapid melting of many different materials and forms (e.g. powder and wire). By the end of the project, 2D printing was demonstrated using lunar regolith simulant. These demonstrations act as an initial proof of concept for solar 3D printing and manufacturing on the Moon using local resources. The capability of producing custom 3D parts from lunar regolith using a compact, lightweight, and energy efficient solar concentrator technology marks a revolutionary innovation for manufacturing on the Moon, which has been targeted for Outward?s ongoing technology development and commercialization efforts. The envisioned solar printer will enable 3D printing of mechanical components from local resources on the Moon without the need for binders or additives. These capabilities will reduce launch costs and dependence on Earth?s resources for upcoming lunar manned and robotic missions by utilizing lunar resources to develop permanent human settlements on the Moon. While Outward Tech?s primary focus for future development is a solar 3D printing system for use on the Moon, it was shown through this project that a consumer solar 3D printer can also be produced, providing a low-cost option for printing metal and glass components.

Outward Tech?s patent-pending ?Light Concentrator System for Precision Thermal Processes? (US #16,711,566) was used in Phase I to achieve unprecedented control over the concentrated solar spot. In general, the solar concentrator technology gives the user the ability to (1) independently control temperature and spot size, (2) maintain constant thermal output over long durations, and (3) achieve extremely high temperatures as compared to conventional electric and gas-powered thermal generation systems. The concentrator technology can deliver these capabilities anywhere in the world with minimal equipment and operating costs. Control over the thermal output allows concentrated solar energy to be used as the heat source in a wide range of high temperature processes including additive manufacturing; welding and cladding; material recycling; pyrolysis of waste streams; sanitizing medical equipment in remote locations; and independent materials science research at very high temperatures.

In general, access to a readily available, sustainable heat source for controlled high temperature applications represents a remarkable tool for individuals, small companies, and underserved communities. A wide host of applications become available to these market participants who must otherwise rely on others to source expensive products and processes generated using specialized facilities and heavy equipment. The solar concentrator technology developed by Outward Tech is the first step to providing these markets with the freedom of a low-cost alternative to many of their most pressing manufacturing and materials processing needs, both on Earth and in space. The technology produces no emissions in its heat generation, requires no fuel costs, and can be used in the most remote of locations.
